sections.summary: The surah affirms the Quran as a source of **guidance** and details signs of **Divine Sovereignty** within the sun, moon, and the alternation of night and day. It promises that those who believe and do good deeds will be guided by their faith to **Gardens of Bliss** [152–153].

Allah describes the human tendency to pray during **adversity** and turn away in ungratefulness once the trial is removed. It records the refusal of the Messenger to alter the **revelation** to suit disbelievers and critiques the error of seeking intercession through **idolatry** [153–154].

Mankind is described as originally a single community before differing, and the parable of the **worldly life** is used to warn against attachment to temporary flourishing. Allah invites humanity to the **Home of Peace** and guides the sincere to a straight path.

This range contrasts the bright reward for the virtuous with the gloom covering the faces of the wicked on the **Day of Gathering**. It exposes the futility of **assumptions** in religious matters and establishes Allah as the only one who originates creation and guides to the **Truth** [155–156].

The text asserts that the Quran is an elaboration of the Book and challenges detractors to produce a **surah** like it. It affirms individual **accountability**, noting that Allah does not wrong people, but they wrong their own souls [156–157].

Every nation is assigned a **messenger** to ensure just judgment, and the Quran is presented as a **healing** and mercy for believers. The text emphasizes Allah's comprehensive knowledge, noting that not even the weight of an **atom** on earth or in the sky escapes His record.

sections.theme: The Friends of Allah and Refutations
sections.summary: The **friends of Allah** are identified as those who believe and are aware, receiving good news in both lives. It refutes the claim that Allah has taken a **son**, labeling such statements as lies fabricated without divine authority [158–159].

sections.theme: The Success of Noah and Moses
sections.summary: Historical narratives of **Noah** and **Moses** illustrate the triumph of those who put their **trust** in Allah against an arrogant elite. Moses confronts the sorcery of Pharaoh's magicians, declaring that Allah will make the efforts of the **corrupt** fail [159–160].

The story of the Exodus culminates in the drowning of Pharaoh and his rejected **deathbed conversion**. Allah preserves his body as a **sign** for future generations, serving as a warning for those who remain heedless of divine revelations.

sections.theme: Children of Israel and Jonah’s People
sections.summary: The text reviews the settling of the Children of Israel and identifies the **People of Jonah** as a unique community whose belief saved them from disgrace. It affirms that **faith** is granted only by Allah's leave and that He saves His messengers by divine decree.

The surah concludes with a call to monotheism and a reminder that Allah is the only one who can remove **harm** or bestow good [161–162]. The Messenger is commanded to follow what is inspired and remain **patient** until Allah issues His final judgment.
